awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Fingerprinting source-to-sink associations for deep-marine vitriclastic deposits and their association to caldera formation on Axial Seamount
awd_abstract_narration:
The most active volcanic provinces in the world are under the sea. Because there is little interference from the thick crustal rocks that form the continents and because the magmas that erupt on the seafloor are closer to and more representative of their source in the mantle, submarine volcanic studies over the last 50 years have helped to transform our knowledge of magma and magma chamber dynamics and evolution. They have also improved our understanding of how the Earth and its tectonic plates work and the cycling of geochemical elements between crustal and mantle reservoirs and vice versa.  This being said, with the exception of a few that peek above the ocean as islands, most seafloor volcanoes lie thousands of meters below the sea surface making it very difficult to know when or how they are erupting.  This research will improve our knowledge of these processes by examining volcanically generated sediments deposited in and around the Axial Volcano caldera 1,400 meters below sealevel and about 500 km off the west coast of Oregon. The research is focused on understanding the history of Axial Volcano caldera formation and determining the mechanisms of vitriclastic formation and the applicability of their use in volcanic stratigraphic studies on undersea volcanoes. Axial is the most thoroughly monitored and sampled seamount in the world. Samples consisting of sediment cores, scoop bags, and rocks as well as bathymetric maps of the caldera at 1 meter resolution will be used in the analysis as will sedimentologic, stratigraphic, and geochemical analytical approaches.  Broader impacts of the project include support of two early career scientists, graduate student training, and use of the new, major, NSF-funded Ocean Observing Initiative network. Impacts also include collaboration with two scientists whose gender is under-represented in the sciences, both of whom are employed at institutions in the EPSCoR states (i.e., states that do not receive significant amounts of federal funding) of Idaho and Rhode Island. Other impacts include international collaboration with German and French scientists and outreach to K-5 schools by producing materials for instruction on volcanoes and volcanic eruptions.

Goals of the research are to define the physical and chemical evolution of Axial Seamount through the time of caldera formation and increase our understanding of submarine volcano eruption styles, fragmentation processes, and vitriclast dispersal mechanisms. Hypotheses to be tested include (1) the physical and chemical characteristics of vitriclastic deposits can be used to fingerprint their eruption, fragmentation, and dispersal origins and (2) lithofacies record magma reservoir deepening associated with magma withdrawal and caldera collapse.Technical The mineralogy of vitriclasts will be examined using X-ray diffraction and scanning electron energy dispersive spectroscopy to constrain their temperature and chemical conditions of origin. Stable isotopes of Hydrogen and Oxygen as well as Cl/K2O ratios will be used to determine magma-seawater interaction during vitriclast fragmentation and seawter assimilation into the magma. A detailed morphometric, textural, and grain size analysis will be carried out to determine if clasts are of phreatomagmatic origin. Magmatic volatiles will be measured in 80 glass inclusions in olivine by secondary ion mass spectrometry from samples taken from vitriclasts.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Project outcomes from this award show that a unique sedimentary deposit on Axial Seamount marks a time of caldera formation that occurred over a ~400 year period. The deposit is widespread on the of the seamount summit, forming a layer that thins from ~40 cm at the caldera margin to where it disappears 3.5 km away. The composition and physical characteristics (e.g. grain size, particle shape) of the deposit indicate that the eruptions that produced it were unusual compared to ?normal? mid-ocean ridge eruptions. The caldera-forming eruptions involved violent magma-water interaction below the seafloor that caused vigorous fragmentation of both magma and the crust that it ascended through. The resulting ash that was expelled from the caldera was confined to the seamount summit due to bottom currents being forced into a rotational pattern. Significant changes to the chemical environment of the bottom waters and/or substrate during this time impacted biologic communities such that the plankton record shows a curious perturbation. Additional work will help elucidate this geobiologic response to mid-ocean ridge caldera formation.

Large scale fractures generated during caldera formation increased permeability of the shallow oceanic crust causing magmas to ascend to the surface relatively un-impeded. This is demonstrated by magma compositions that are relatively primitive, meaning that they did not stall and cool in the shallow crust. Instead they ascended to the surface somewhat rapidly, likely due to a more permeable shallow crust. Future crustal permeability modelling will help constrain the impacts that caldera formation can have on ascending mid-ocean ridge magmas. Changes to the subseafloor architecture of the magmatic plumbing system are also suggested by volatile contents, namely CO2 and H2O, trapped within crystal melt inclusions. These volatile data show that the magma chamber below the caldera reduced in size and shallowed following caldera formation. Moreover, these data also indicate that the mantle source below Axial Seamount is relatively enriched in volatiles and more akin to other hot-spot affected mid-ocean ridge segments like Iceland. Said volatile enrichment may be a reason why Axial Seamount, compared to more normal mid-ocean ridge segments (non-hot spot affected), contain such a robust record of magmatic fragmentation and ?explosive? eruptions on the seafloor. The exact physical nature of these ?explosive? eruptions however, are better termed ?implosive?, as recently suggested by a publication in Earth and Planetary Science Letters (2022) written by the post-doc, A. Murch, while he was funded on this award.

Broader Impacts

This project supported an early career PI as he transitioned from being a post-doc to a tenure track faculty. Through this transition PI Portner developed the skills to mentor a post-doc (A. Murch), 3 graduate students and 2 undergraduate students. In turn, the post doc also mentored a graduate student and the graduate students mentored undergraduate students. Upon writing this final outcome the PI has applied for tenure and recently received notification that his application is excellent and nominated for acceptance. The research, scholarship and creative activities to results from this project have in many ways been a strong component of his tenure application.

New collaboration to result from this project within the PI?s home institution (SJSU) resulted in the success of a proposal for an internal seed grant to investigate the geobiologic response to caldera formation. A new full NSF proposal is now planned to follow. Overseas travel supported by this project also allowed the PI and his first MS graduate student to work in a tier 1 volcanology lab in France. This was the first time either individual travelled to France and left a lasting impression on both. Finally, this project also helped attract a post-doc from New Zealand to work with PI Portner, and they both established new collaboration with colleagues at the University of Washington Applied Physics Lab and the University of Bergen Deepsea Centre of research.

Some of the exciting results from this project were integrated into classroom learning activities and experiments developed by PI Portner and his advanced sedimentology graduate class. Together the team travelled to suburban and urban school districts in and around San Jose California. The student body of the urban school is made up of 96% student that are considered to be  minority and 64% considered to be economically disadvantaged, whom have very little access to STEM based education. Now that the connection between Portner and the school teachers has been established he plans to expand this work to other schools in the community.
